VOL. XXV. No. 9
FIRST "PLAY NIGHT" OF
DRAMATIC CLUB WELL
ATTENDED.
Two Playlets Presented Successfully.
Undergraduate Orchestra Adds to
The Evening's Enjoyment.

The first "play night" of the
Dramatic Club held last Tuesday
night in the club's studio in the
"Barn" was more of a success than
ever anticipated. The "theater"
was crowded to its seating capacity and at 8.20 o'clock it was found
necessary to erect a "standing
room only" sign. The audience
was composed largely of persons
unconnected with the University,
all of whom were very enthusiastic
over the plays. The student-body
was poorly represented.
The first playlet was a fantasy
by E. M. Basford entitled "Three
Friends" and was followed by
Joseph Moran's "Triangle Extraordinary." For a long time it was
thought better to have the fantasy
come after the melodrama so as to
leave a pleasant scene in the minds
of the audience, but it was found
that to put up the trees and their
branches would require much more
time than to take them down.
The, casts of the plays were as
follows:
"Three Friends"—The Boy, Joe
Moran, '23;
p23;the Mother E. F.
Spirit of Night,
Buchner,
Glover Fallon, '23; Soul of the
Trees, Frank R. Smith, '21; Soul
of thern BroOk, C. Holzoppel, '23.
"The Triangle Extraordinary"
—Lester, Pearce Brawner, '23;
Margaret Graham, 0. iesser•
Messersmith,'23; George B. Jenifer,'24;
Boggs, G. L. Sadtler, '23.
Joe Moran as the hero of "Three
Friends" made an excellent "Boy"
and gave a very good interpretation of his part. The "Spirits,"
though on for only a short time,
gave very creditable interpretations of their roles, which were
rather difficult for men. Buchner
as the "Mother" was very impressive.
The second play, a,clever sketch
by Moran, was, perhaps if there
was any, difference, the'
better of
the two from the student's point
of view. The acting was not at all
Perfect, but was saved by the
rather clever lines inserted by the
author. Pearce Brawner as Lester
played the part very well, but was
most affected. Jenifer whose part
was that of a mah whose
' identity
is unknown, but who is taken -for
George Graham, was the most
natural of them all, even though
he did not have more than ten
lines to say.
3/Iessersmith made- a very effective heroine and Sadtler a very
good butler.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 30, 1920

BLACK AND BLUE LOSE STATE
CHAMPIONSHIP

PRICE 10 CENTS
GRADUATION HURTS BALL
TEAM.
Only Six Regulars Return—Management Arranging Good Schedule.
Armstrong Continues as Coach.

Maryland State Defeats Hopkins Eleven in Deciding
Struggle on Homewood Field by
Score of 24-7.

In one of the greatest battles ever seen on Homefield Field, the
University of Maryland won the State football championship on
Thanksgiving Day by defeating Hopkins, 24 to 7.
The game was in every sense a fitting climax to the fall season, for
both teams had won all their contests with Maryland elevens, and both
were at the very peak of their development and power. Stands packed
to capacity with supporters of the two squads looked down on the field
and shouted encouragement, while the music of the rival bands and a
brisk wind set the spectators on edge for a close fight.
The bare score gives little indication of how hotly contested the
game was. Both Hopkins and Maryland had what were perhaps the
most powerful elevens ever to represent the two institutions. Few
gains of consequence were made on straight football, but each score
followed something in the nature of a break, and most of the breaks
were in the College Parker's favor. The contest might well be called
a game of "almost" touchdowns for Hopkins, for once in the second
quarter a clever fake kick came dangerously near putting the ball over,
while the end of the game found the Black and Blue with a scant yard
to go and a score almost a certainty.
The work of Bill and Ed Wood
on the ends was one of the greatest factors in keeping the score
down. Not once did Brewer or
the other State bhcks get away for
a respectable run after a punt, and
few, indeed, were the end runs
that gained more than a yard or
so. In addition, Ed recovered a
fumble and ran 40 yards before being pulled down.
Morgan and Totterdale also
stood out prominently, for it was
"Til" who broke through and recovered the ball on Maryland's 10yard line, making possible Hop.
kins' touchdown, while Totterdale,
playing a roving center, was a
tower of strength on the defense.
It is a matter of fact that the
whole line exhibited a style of
football that could hardly be improved on.
The almost air-tight defensive
work of both elevens kept the backfields from getting away for frequent gains of• any. length. All
the Hopkins backs made clever
runs at'times against the bitterest
of opposition, while Jones came

through with a brilliant dash of 30
yards from a kickoff. Brewer was
the real star for State on the offensive; his run of 50 yards was
the longest of the game, and his
punts probably the best ever seen
in Baltimore. Mackert failed to
live up to what was expected of
him, although he played an excellent and a consistent game.
Maryland's first score came during the first quarter. After some
minutes of play, in which the.opposing teams tested each other for
possible weak spots, one of Brewer's punts struck Jones on the head
and was recovered by State. On
the next play Mackert fumbled,
Gregg recovering, but another
fumble by Markell gave the ball
back to Maryland. Here a series
of line plunges and a pass over
the goal line gave the College
Parkers a touchdown.
State scored again in the second
quarter, after a 15-yard penalty
and a 12-yard run by Brewer had
carried the ball to Within 5 yards
of the goal.

The 1921 baseball management
has already succeeded in arranging the skeleton of a very good
schedule for the coming season.
By this Hopkins will meet some
of the leading teams of the country—among them Princeton', Penn
State, University of Virginia,
Swarthmore and Wesleyan. The
majority of the games will be
played at Homewood, although the
team will take its customary
Northern trip. Care has also been
taken to have no games scheduled
to take,place on consecutive days,
as was, unfortunately for the
pitching staff, the case upon several occasions last year.
The outlook for a successfui
season cannot be said to be particularly bright on account of the
majority of last year's players
having graduated. or completed
their four years of college baseball. Owings, on the mound, and
Bill Wood, behind the bat, are the
only members of last' year's battery to return to the University,
while Sharretts, captain of the
1921 team is the only regular infielder back, he having held down
third base last season. The outfield has not fared so poorly, as
Dick Benson, centerfield, is the
only one to have left, Andy Knecht
and "Doc" Cox both expecting to
be on hand when the curtain goes
up—Elmer Jones, the well-known
"Turkey" of football fame has
also won his baseball "H," having
played in the field on the 1919
team, but was unable to play last
season. If he can join the squad
this year he will, of course, put up
some strong competition for his
old position in the outfield.
The four members of last year's
successful Frosh team Merrick,
Clark, Middleton and Miller, have
returned and should be likely
candidates for this season's Varsity. "Herb" Reifsneider, subinfielder last year, is expected to
place himself high up in the competition this spring.
Nothing definite is known as yet
of this year's Frosh, but there is,
of course, the possibility of there
being some good material among
"them.
The A. A. Board "Committee on
Recommending a Coach" has
picked H. E. Armstrong, who held
that position last year. In defense of Mr. Armst'rong, it should
be said that the rather mediocre

BASKETEERS.
Many Candidates Expected to Turn

Will Probably Include Two
Northern Trips.

HAT man doesn't like his pipe? There's nothing whets
your smoke desires like seeing a good pipe lying around.
Because you know that in it is the only real smoke satisfaction.
Your appetite will be doubly whetted if it is a W D C, because in
W D C Pipes all the sweetness and mellowness of the genuine
French briar is brought out by our own special seasoning process.
Then, too, W D C Iiipes are good to look at. The designs are
pleasing and workmanship perfect. You'll agree with us that our
craftsmen are accomplishing their purpose—to make pipes that
are without peers in all the world. Ask any good dealer. Be
sure and look for the Triangle trademark. It's a guarantee against
cracking or burning through.

The basketball team will be
coached this year by Major Louis
E. Lamborn, Director of Athletics
at Friends School. Every Hopkins man knows Major Lamborn
either personally or through the
wonderful fighting teams he has
turned out at Friends School.
Those who were at Camp Red
Cloud know what an enthusiastic
and inspiring leader he is. The
mere fact that he will direct the
basketball team this year augurs
well for its success.
But other indications are not
lacking to point to a winning
team. At the organization, meeting to be held Friday Capt.'"Bill'
Wood expects an unusually large
and skilled turnout. There are
many former prep school stars at
the University this year and three
of last year's five are back.
It is probable that a great majority of the football men will be
on hand when Major Lamborn
starts the ball rolling. Dr. Van
Orman is strong for basketball as
a training for football and many
gridiron stars will probably take
up the game. The first practice
will be held December 6.
The schedule while not yet
ready for official announcement
will in all probability include two
extensive northern trips. All home
games will be played at the
Armory and the dances after the
games, which were so successful
last year, will be given this year
also.

NEW LOCAL PETITIONING
INTER-FRATERNITY
BOARD.
The Beta-Beta Fraternity, a new
organization at Johns Hopkins
has made its appearance and has
petitioned the Inter-Fraternity
Board for recognition. In accordance with the new ruling of
the board a fraternity must pass
through one semester on probation
before it may have voting power
on the fraternity board.
The organization was founded
as a club last year and it is just
recently that it has become a fraternity.
The present headquarters are at 20 East Thirty-fourth
street, but it will not be until next
fall that a permanent house will
be chosen.

SOPHOMORES HOLD
CLASS-MEETING.•
The Sophomore class-meeting
last week developed into a rather
riotous affair. The storm broke
after the class had appointed
Norvell Miller and Henry-West to
the Cotillion Board and had voted
down a resolution,by Joe Thompson to put the new non-athletic fee
into operation this year as far as
the class of 1923 was concerned.

Milton Goldstein got the floor
and immediately started to assail
the class and the university as a
whole for its lack of proper preparation for the University of Maryland game. He accused the class
of total lack of spirit and demanded that if the student and
cheer-leader were "dead from the
neck up" that the class should
start things rolling: What the
class did do, and how it resp"Onded
to Goldstein's rough treatment is
now a matter of history. The
preparation for the game was thoroughly satisfactory and worthy of
true Hopkins•spirit.

"What a splendid fit," said the
tailor, as they• carried the epileptic out of his shop.—Record.

The ability of the club to overcome the limitations for scenery
and lighting is indeed to be
praised. Great work was entailed
in getting in a searchlight with
rheostats attached and effective
foot and back lights. The painting was under the supervision of
Mr. Mariano Badillo, for whose
efforts the club is greatly indebted.
The trees in the first play were
made from the old leggings used
in "The Admirable Crichton" and
the "leather" upholstery in the second play from benches and chairs
in common use at the University
padded with cushions and covered
with unbleached muslin.
The receipts taken in at the door
were just enough to cover expenses. Mike Bower's new orchestra was stationed down stairs in
the Y. M. C. A. reception room and
furnished an excellent musical program for the whole evening. The
audience was served with cake and
punch after the plays were over.
It is thought probable that these
same playlets will be repeated
within a few days and that more
of the students will take the advantage of seeing all Hopkins performances.

supper and smoker last Wednesday evening.

ALUMNI.

The following news item has
been received from the Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing
Co.:
H. H. Startzman, B.S.,'19, after
graduation entered the employ of
the Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co. at East Pittsburgh
as a graduate student, which work
he completed early in the spring
of the present year. His record
as a graduate student had been
one of such success that the chief
engineer of the company assigned
him to special training for a pe
mod of six months under his immediate supervision. This work
is now completed, and Mr. Startzman has entered the employ of the
company in its industrial engineering department.

A meeting of the Scabbard and
Blade was held Tuesday evening,
November 23, at which Lieut. 0. S.
Wilkinson, '22, was initiated into
the society. The meeting was preceded by a dinner at the Hopkins
Club. Major Garey and Captain
McMurray were present and gave
informal talks in which they discussed R.0. T. C. matters. An opportunity was then extended to
every member of Seabbard and
Blade to make suggestions for improving the unit and correcting
difficulties which had been encountered. The organization of a rifle
club to represent Hopkins in intercollegiate shooting matches was
discussed and the subject referred
to a committee of four for investigation and report.
The Scabbard and Blade is a
national honorary military society, comprising at present two
regiments with a total of 22 companies, each company-chapter at a
college or university conferring
baccalaureate degrees, and maintaining a senior R. 0. T. C. or
cadet corps. Cadet officers are
eligible to membership and election to the society is based on
merit and proficiency in military
science. The society believes that
military service is an obligation of
citizenship, and that the greater
opportunities afforded college men
for the study of military science
place upon them certain responsibilities as citizens. Its purpose is
to unite in closer relationship the
military departments of American
universities; to_ preserve and develop the essential qualities of
good and efficient officers; to prepare its members as educated men
to take a more active part and to
have a greater influence in the
military affairs of the communities in which they may reside, and
above all to spread intelligent information concerning the military
requirements of our country.
This company of the Scabbard
and Blade was formed in the
spring a last year. Fred Bresee,
420, was chosen captain. The officers for this year were elected just
before the close of school last year,
as follows: Cadet Major C. F.
Chisholm, Captain; Capt. T.• F.
Hubbard, First Lieutenant; Capt.
B. F. Sollers, Second Lieutenant,
and Capt. T. L. Berry, First Sergeant. Other members now at the
University are Captains E. H.
Shaw, J. G. Douglas, R. B. Smith
and L. W. Call. President Goodnow and Major Garey are honorary members of the chapter, and
Captain McMurray is a Scabbard
and Blade alumnus of the Cornell
company.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Sir—Columbia University last
year inaugurated a system of
awarding what is known as a
Freshman activity button to every
first-year man who responded to
the call of extra-curricular work.
The button served to distinguish
the Freshmen with college spirit
from,their inactive classmates.
To take charge of the awarding
of these buttons, a member of the
Student Board of Columbia is appointed yearly. To him the managers of activities, both athletic
and non-athletic turn in the lists
of names of candidates who have
fulfilled the obligations necessary
to be entitled to buttons.
The buttons are about the size
of a fraternity pledge pin and are
worn on the coat lapel. Being of
gold with an embossed king's
crown enameled in blue and white,
they are really attractive. They
may be retained permanently only
if at the end of the season the
Freshman is retained by the sport,
publication or society he went out
for.
There are many inactive men on
the campus who do not realize just
how many of their fellow classmen
are promoting some activity. This
is especially true among Freshmen.
Columbia's system, copied at
Hopkins, would offer an incentive
for every Freshman to get into
some activity and be one of the
"regular fellows" on the campus.
It would show just who are Hopkins men and who are not.
Very truly yours,
SENIOR.
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Sir—The NEWS-LETTER reminds
me of a story told by Mr.
Henry Watterson of a wag (the
famous Gilbert) approaching him
and the editor of Punch and addressing the latter with, "I suppose you get some mighty articles
submitted to you." "We certainly
do," replied the editor of Punch.
"Then why the devil don't you publish some of them?" rejoined Mr.
Gilbert.
ARTHUR A. DEMBITZ.

FIRST "PLAY NIGHT" OF
DRAMATIC CLUB WELL
ATTENDED.
Two Playlets Presented Successfully.
Undergraduate Orchestra Adds to
The Evening's Enjoyment.

The first "play night" of the
Dramatic Club held last Tuesday
night in the club's studio in the
"Barn" was more of a success than
ever anticipated. The "theater"
was crowded to its seating capacity and at 8.20 o'clock it was found
necessary to erect a "standing
room only" sign. The audience
was composed largely of persons
unconnected with the University,
all of whom were very enthusiastic
over the plays. The student-body
was poorly represented.
The first playlet was a fantasy
by E. M. Basford entitled "Three
Friends" and was followed by
Joseph Moran's "Triangle Extraordinary." For a long time it was
thought better to have the fantasy
come after the melodrama so as to
leave a pleasant scene in the minds
of the audience, but it was found
that to put up the trees and their
branches would require much more
time than to take them down.
The, casts of the plays were as
follows:
"Three Friends"—The Boy, Joe
Moran, '23;
p23;the Mother E. F.
Spirit of Night,
Buchner,
Glover Fallon, '23; Soul of the
Trees, Frank R. Smith, '21; Soul
of thern BroOk, C. Holzoppel, '23.
"The Triangle Extraordinary"
—Lester, Pearce Brawner, '23;
Margaret Graham, 0. iesser•
Messersmith,'23; George B. Jenifer,'24;
Boggs, G. L. Sadtler, '23.
Joe Moran as the hero of "Three
Friends" made an excellent "Boy"
and gave a very good interpretation of his part. The "Spirits,"
though on for only a short time,
gave very creditable interpretations of their roles, which were
rather difficult for men. Buchner
as the "Mother" was very impressive.
The second play, a,clever sketch
by Moran, was, perhaps if there
was any, difference, the'
better of
the two from the student's point
of view. The acting was not at all
Perfect, but was saved by the
rather clever lines inserted by the
author. Pearce Brawner as Lester
played the part very well, but was
most affected. Jenifer whose part
was that of a mah whose
' identity
is unknown, but who is taken -for
George Graham, was the most
natural of them all, even though
he did not have more than ten
lines to say.
3/Iessersmith made- a very effective heroine and Sadtler a very
good butler.

Maryland State Defeats Hopkins Eleven in Deciding
Struggle on Homewood Field by
Score of 24-7.

In one of the greatest battles ever seen on Homefield Field, the
University of Maryland won the State football championship on
Thanksgiving Day by defeating Hopkins, 24 to 7.
The game was in every sense a fitting climax to the fall season, for
both teams had won all their contests with Maryland elevens, and both
were at the very peak of their development and power. Stands packed
to capacity with supporters of the two squads looked down on the field
and shouted encouragement, while the music of the rival bands and a
brisk wind set the spectators on edge for a close fight.
The bare score gives little indication of how hotly contested the
game was. Both Hopkins and Maryland had what were perhaps the
most powerful elevens ever to represent the two institutions. Few
gains of consequence were made on straight football, but each score
followed something in the nature of a break, and most of the breaks
were in the College Parker's favor. The contest might well be called
a game of "almost" touchdowns for Hopkins, for once in the second
quarter a clever fake kick came dangerously near putting the ball over,
while the end of the game found the Black and Blue with a scant yard
to go and a score almost a certainty.
The work of Bill and Ed Wood
on the ends was one of the greatest factors in keeping the score
down. Not once did Brewer or
the other State bhcks get away for
a respectable run after a punt, and
few, indeed, were the end runs
that gained more than a yard or
so. In addition, Ed recovered a
fumble and ran 40 yards before being pulled down.
Morgan and Totterdale also
stood out prominently, for it was
"Til" who broke through and recovered the ball on Maryland's 10yard line, making possible Hop.
kins' touchdown, while Totterdale,
playing a roving center, was a
tower of strength on the defense.
It is a matter of fact that the
whole line exhibited a style of
football that could hardly be improved on.
The almost air-tight defensive
work of both elevens kept the backfields from getting away for frequent gains of• any. length. All
the Hopkins backs made clever
runs at'times against the bitterest
of opposition, while Jones came

through with a brilliant dash of 30
yards from a kickoff. Brewer was
the real star for State on the offensive; his run of 50 yards was
the longest of the game, and his
punts probably the best ever seen
in Baltimore. Mackert failed to
live up to what was expected of
him, although he played an excellent and a consistent game.
Maryland's first score came during the first quarter. After some
minutes of play, in which the.opposing teams tested each other for
possible weak spots, one of Brewer's punts struck Jones on the head
and was recovered by State. On
the next play Mackert fumbled,
Gregg recovering, but another
fumble by Markell gave the ball
back to Maryland. Here a series
of line plunges and a pass over
the goal line gave the College
Parkers a touchdown.
State scored again in the second
quarter, after a 15-yard penalty
and a 12-yard run by Brewer had
carried the ball to Within 5 yards
of the goal.
Mackert then

The 1921 baseball management
has already succeeded in arranging the skeleton of a very good
schedule for the coming season.
By this Hopkins will meet some
of the leading teams of the country—among them Princeton', Penn
State, University of Virginia,
Swarthmore and Wesleyan. The
majority of the games will be
played at Homewood, although the
team will take its customary
Northern trip. Care has also been
taken to have no games scheduled
to take,place on consecutive days,
as was, unfortunately for the
pitching staff, the case upon several occasions last year.
The outlook for a successfui
season cannot be said to be particularly bright on account of the
majority of last year's players
having graduated. or completed
their four years of college baseball. Owings, on the mound, and
Bill Wood, behind the bat, are the
only members of last' year's battery to return to the University,
while Sharretts, captain of the
1921 team is the only regular infielder back, he having held down
third base last season. The outfield has not fared so poorly, as
Dick Benson, centerfield, is the
only one to have left, Andy Knecht
and "Doc" Cox both expecting to
be on hand when the curtain goes
up—Elmer Jones, the well-known
"Turkey" of football fame has
also won his baseball "H," having
played in the field on the 1919
team, but was unable to play last
season. If he can join the squad
this year he will, of course, put up
some strong competition for his
old position in the outfield.
The four members of last year's
successful Frosh team Merrick,
Clark, Middleton and Miller, have
returned and should be likely
candidates for this season's Varsity. "Herb" Reifsneider, subinfielder last year, is expected to
place himself high up in the competition this spring.

The basketball team will be
coached this year by Major Louis
E. Lamborn, Director of Athletics
at Friends School. Every Hopkins man knows Major Lamborn
either personally or through the
wonderful fighting teams he has
turned out at Friends School.
Those who were at Camp Red
Cloud know what an enthusiastic
and inspiring leader he is. The
mere fact that he will direct the
basketball team this year augurs
well for its success.
But other indications are not
lacking to point to a winning
team. At the organization, meeting to be held Friday Capt.'"Bill'
Wood expects an unusually large
and skilled turnout. There are
many former prep school stars at
the University this year and three
of last year's five are back.
It is probable that a great majority of the football men will be
on hand when Major Lamborn
starts the ball rolling. Dr. Van
Orman is strong for basketball as
a training for football and many
gridiron stars will probably take
up the game. The first practice
will be held December 6.
The schedule while not yet
ready for official announcement
will in all probability include two
extensive northern trips. All home
games will be played at the
Armory and the dances after the
games, which were so successful
last year, will be given this year
also.

BOARD.
The Beta-Beta Fraternity, a new
organization at Johns Hopkins
has made its appearance and has
petitioned the Inter-Fraternity
Board for recognition. In accordance with the new ruling of
the board a fraternity must pass
through one semester on probation
before it may have voting power
on the fraternity board.
The organization was founded
as a club last year and it is just
recently that it has become a fraternity.
The present headquarters are at 20 East Thirty-fourth
street, but it will not be until next
fall that a permanent house will
be chosen.

SOPHOMORES HOLD
CLASS-MEETING.•
The Sophomore class-meeting
last week developed into a rather
riotous affair. The storm broke
after the class had appointed
Norvell Miller and Henry-West to
the Cotillion Board and had voted
down a resolution,by Joe Thompson to put the new non-athletic fee
into operation this year as far as
the class of 1923 was concerned.

Milton Goldstein got the floor
and immediately started to assail
the class and the university as a
whole for its lack of proper preparation for the University of Maryland game. He accused the class
of total lack of spirit and demanded that if the student and
cheer-leader were "dead from the
neck up" that the class should
start things rolling: What the
class did do, and how it resp"Onded
to Goldstein's rough treatment is
now a matter of history. The
preparation for the game was thoroughly satisfactory and worthy of
true Hopkins•spirit.

"What a splendid fit," said the
tailor, as they• carried the epileptic out of his shop.—Record.

The ability of the club to overcome the limitations for scenery
and lighting is indeed to be
praised. Great work was entailed
in getting in a searchlight with
rheostats attached and effective
foot and back lights. The painting was under the supervision of
Mr. Mariano Badillo, for whose
efforts the club is greatly indebted.
The trees in the first play were
made from the old leggings used
in "The Admirable Crichton" and
the "leather" upholstery in the second play from benches and chairs
in common use at the University
padded with cushions and covered
with unbleached muslin.
The receipts taken in at the door
were just enough to cover expenses. Mike Bower's new orchestra was stationed down stairs in
the Y. M. C. A. reception room and
furnished an excellent musical program for the whole evening. The
audience was served with cake and
punch after the plays were over.
It is thought probable that these
same playlets will be repeated
within a few days and that more
of the students will take the advantage of seeing all Hopkins performances.

The following news item has
been received from the Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing
Co.:
H. H. Startzman, B.S.,'19, after
graduation entered the employ of

A meeting of the Scabbard and
Blade was held Tuesday evening,
November 23, at which Lieut. 0. S.
Wilkinson, '22, was initiated into
the society. The meeting was preceded by a dinner at the Hopkins
Club. Major Garey and Captain
McMurray were present and gave
informal talks in which they discussed R.0. T. C. matters. An opportunity was then extended to
every member of Seabbard and
Blade to make suggestions for improving the unit and correcting
difficulties which had been encountered. The organization of a rifle
club to represent Hopkins in intercollegiate shooting matches was
discussed and the subject referred
to a committee of four for investigation and report.
The Scabbard and Blade is a
national honorary military society, comprising at present two
regiments with a total of 22 companies, each company-chapter at a
college or university conferring
baccalaureate degrees, and maintaining a senior R. 0. T. C. or
cadet corps. Cadet officers are
eligible to membership and election to the society is based on
merit and proficiency in military
science. The society believes that
military service is an obligation of
citizenship, and that the greater
opportunities afforded college men
for the study of military science
place upon them certain responsibilities as citizens. Its purpose is
to unite in closer relationship the
military departments of American
universities; to_ preserve and develop the essential qualities of
good and efficient officers; to prepare its members as educated men
to take a more active part and to
have a greater influence in the
military affairs of the communities in which they may reside, and
above all to spread intelligent information concerning the military
requirements of our country.
This company of the Scabbard
and Blade was formed in the
spring a last year. Fred Bresee,
420, was chosen captain. The officers for this year were elected just
before the close of school last year,
as follows: Cadet Major C. F.
Chisholm, Captain; Capt. T.• F.
Hubbard, First Lieutenant; Capt.
B. F. Sollers, Second Lieutenant,
and Capt. T. L. Berry, First Sergeant. Other members now at the
University are Captains E. H.
Shaw, J. G. Douglas, R. B. Smith
and L. W. Call. President Goodnow and Major Garey are honorary members of the chapter, and

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Sir—Columbia University last
year inaugurated a system of
awarding what is known as a
Freshman activity button to every
first-year man who responded to
the call of extra-curricular work.
The button served to distinguish
the Freshmen with college spirit
from,their inactive classmates.
To take charge of the awarding
of these buttons, a member of the
Student Board of Columbia is appointed yearly. To him the managers of activities, both athletic
and non-athletic turn in the lists
of names of candidates who have
fulfilled the obligations necessary
to be entitled to buttons.
The buttons are about the size
of a fraternity pledge pin and are
worn on the coat lapel. Being of
gold with an embossed king's
crown enameled in blue and white,
they are really attractive. They
may be retained permanently only
if at the end of the season the
Freshman is retained by the sport,
publication or society he went out
for.
There are many inactive men on
the campus who do not realize just
how many of their fellow classmen
are promoting some activity. This
is especially true among Freshmen.
Columbia's system, copied at
Hopkins, would offer an incentive
for every Freshman to get into
some activity and be one of the
"regular fellows" on the campus.
It would show just who are Hopkins men and who are not.
Very truly yours,
SENIOR.
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Sir—The NEWS-LETTER reminds
me of a story told by Mr.
Henry Watterson of a wag (the
famous Gilbert) approaching him
and the editor of Punch and addressing the latter with, "I suppose you get some mighty articles
submitted to you." "We certainly
do," replied the editor of Punch.
"Then why the devil don't you publish some of them?" rejoined Mr.
Gilbert.
ARTHUR A. DEMBITZ.

LAST OF SYRIAN LECTURES
GIVEN.
Last week Dr. Frederick Jones
Bliss delivered the last of a series
of six lectures on "The Secret
Cults of Syria." Dr. Bliss had
delivered the same course of lectures at the University of Pennsylvania before coming to • Hopkins. He is the author of "A
Mound of Many Cities," "Excavations at Jerusalem," "The Religions of Modern Syria and Palestine," etc. The lectures are being
given at different colleges _under
the auspices of the American Committee for Lectures on the History
of Religions.
